title: DT Swiss updates CRC 1400 Spline CX wheelset with return to hooked rims
content:
Cyclist
DT Swiss updates CRC 1400 Spline CX wheelset with return to hooked rims

DT Swiss has updated its CRC 1400 Spline cyclocross wheelset, with the latest version reverting to hooked rims from its predecessor’s hookless design. That’s added slightly to the weight, but DT Swiss says it ensures broader compatibility with cyclocross tyres.

The rim is now considerably deeper as well, moving up to 35mm and 45mm options from their predecessor’s 24mm depth. While DT Swiss’s gravel wheels such as the GRC 1400 Spline 42 have an internal rim width of 24mm, the CRC 1400 splits the difference with the road range at 22mm.

The wheels are priced at £779.99  / $1007.90 / €860.90 for the front and £1084.99 / $1391.90 / €1188.90 for the rear wheel, and are available now.

Cyclocross-specific wheels

We’re used to everything being made gravel-specific, but DT Swiss says that the CRC 1400 Spline wheelset is designed specifically for cyclocross races. It’s available for the first time in two rim depths, 35mm and 45mm, in place of its predecessor’s 24mm.

The brand says that the 35mm profile is designed for efficiency in technical courses, while the deeper sections wheels are geared more towards robustness for longer courses and greater aero advantage.

As with its road wheelsets, DT Swiss has partnered with Swiss Side to wind tunnel test and aero optimise the wheels. The brand specifically mentions their crosswind stability – important if the winter weather turns wild for a cyclocross race.

This tubeless-ready wheelset is designed to allow easy tyre swaps, which is another feature useful in cyclocross, where matching the tyres to the course conditions on the day can give the rider a vital edge. DT Swiss says it’s worked with major tyre companies to ensure compatibility.

Most serious cyclocross racers travel with several different wheelsets, set up with different tyres, so they can easily switch when they arrive at the course and have assessed the terrain. Nevertheless, the option to quickly set up wheels with tyres that give the right level of traction and grip for the course is still important.

Why the return to hooked rims?

Given the lower tyre pressure than road bike tyres at which cyclocross tyres are ridden, the swap back to hooked rims is somewhat unexpected. There’s far less risk of a tyre blowing off the rim at lower pressure and the trend for tubeless road bike wheels is towards hookless rim designs, with brands including Zipp and Enve going fully hookless for their road and gravel wheelsets. 

But the very low pressures typically run for cyclocross and the vicissitudes of cyclocross courses bring their own problems. Burping, where the tyre detaches from the rim and loses air, can be an issue, although the wider contact patch between the wheel rim and tyre with a hookless design can help to preserve the seal. At low pressures and under high traction it’s also possible to completely unseat the tyre, effectively putting you out of the race.

DT Swiss says the return to hooked rims also provides compatibility with a wider range of tyres and tyre sizes than a hookless design.

One advantage cited for hookless rims is their lower weight, but DT Swiss has managed to add back the hooks with minimal extra mass, with the new wheelset weighing a claimed 1,415g in 35mm depth and 1,466g for the 45mm deep profile, as against the shallower previous generation’s 1,389g.

The DT Swiss CRC 1400 Spline wheels turn on the brand’s trusty 240 Spline hubs, with the Ratchet EXP freehub, which is lighter than the previous generation freehub’s Ratchet System. 

DT Swiss has redesigned the 240 Spline’s hub body and says that it’s slimmer and stiffer, improving aerodynamics and durability. There’s compatibility with Shimano/SRAM 11/12-speed road and SRAM XDR freehubs, but not Campagnolo.

The wheels are laced with 24 two-crossed straight-pull spokes front and rear, with DT Swiss Aerolites at the front and Aerocomps out back. The alloy nipples are hidden in the rim. Corrosion problems with alloy nipples isn’t as big a problem as it used to be, but we do wonder if the internal placement means they’ll stay wetter and muddier for longer than external nipples, if moisture finds its way inside the rim.

DT Swiss CRC 1400 Spline specifications

  • Thru-axle compatibility: 100×12mm front, 142×12mm rear
  • Hub: DT Swiss 240 Spline, 36 tooth Ratchet XP freehub
  • Freehub compatibility: Shimano/SRAM road, SRAM XDR
  • Rim height: 35mm/45mm
  • Rim internal width: 22mm
  • Spokes: 24 × 2-cross DT Swiss aerolite F, aerocomp R, with hidden alloy nipples
  • Claimed weight 35mm depth: 1,415g, 647g F, 768g R
  • Claimed weight 45mm depth: 1,466g, 673g F, 793g R
  • Weight limit: 120kg
  • Price Front: £779.99  / $1007.90 / €860.90 
  • Price Rear: £1084.99 / $1391.90 / €1188.90
